direction.raw_text: Bird's-eye view. We circle lazily above the forest. Through a break in the trees, we catch an occasional glimpse of a prostrate form on the ground. As the circling camera gets closer we see that the form is a human body.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OF LILA TALKING TO THE CAMERA LILA

direction.raw_text: -UP OF LILA TALKING TO THE CAMERA LILA I'm not sorry. A bead of sweat trickles down her cheek. Then: a blinding flash of light obliterates her face.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OF PUFF TALKING TO THE CAMERA PUFF

direction.raw_text: -UP OF PUFF TALKING TO THE CAMERA PUFF I am sorry. A tear wells in Puff's eye and runs down his face. Another blinding flash of light.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OF NATHAN TALKING TO THE CAMERA NATHAN

direction.raw_text: -UP OF NATHAN TALKING TO THE CAMERA NATHAN I don't even know what sorry means anymore. As Nathan speaks, a trickle of blood drips down his face from his out-of-frame forehead. Another blinding flash of light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a frenetic hand-held shot as Lila is pulled from a police car and dragged into the precinct house. Cameras flash. Reporters shout questions. Lila attempts to shield her face from view, but she is handcuffed and can only manage to hunch her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A ratty interrogation room. Institutional green walls. Beat-up file cabinets. Dark. A bit of fluorescent light spills in through the frosted glass door. Lila, thirties, sits at the end of a long table. A reel-to-reel tape recorder whirs in front of her. She is smoking. Three fat, mean-looking cops sit in shadows at the other end of the table. One of the cops eyes her lasciviously. Lila's hand shakes as she brings the cigarette to her mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the cops sighs and massages the bridge of his nose. It's going to be a long night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lascivious cop smiles lasciviously at Lila's reference to "human body."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lascivious cop gags, then vomits on the floor. Lila drags on her cigarette, calmer now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sorry. So I spend the rest of my life in jail. So what? I've been in jail my whole life anyway. A jail of blood and tissue and coursing hormones...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...a jail called the human body.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My soul held prisoner in this reeking, stench-ridden bag of bones and entrails. A bag of feces and piss and fibroid cysts in my tits and precancerous moles on my sun-damaged back...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least now I'll be able to blame the state, not God, for my incarceration.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Puff, thirties, dirty, scraggly hair and beard but in a crisp business suit, testifies before a congressional committee. The auditorium is filled with reporters and spectators. Puff sits in front of a microphone, counsel at his side. He pours himself a glass of water, drinks, clears his throat, then speaks: stentorian, confident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a revelation to the assembled crowd. People whisper to each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I am sorry, gentlemen, sorry for all of us. Your's is a complicated, sad world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I never knew that. I was living a life of simplicity, of purity, when I was ripped out of my Eden and immersed in this harshness. Some would argue that the life I was living was not a human life at all. And, gentlemen, I don't have any clever retort. I am not a philosopher. The only thing I know is that I am sorry, sorry for my expulsion from Eden, sorry for my Lila rotting in her jail cell, and sorry for Nathan... rotting in his grave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Nathan, thirties, in a white robe, sits alone at a white table. Everything is white except for an oozing bullet wound in Nathan's temple.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't even know what sorry means anymore. It's odd. When I was alive I knew -- maybe it was all I knew -- but here sorry is meaningless. Love is meaningless. Jealousy is meaningless. Ambition is meaningless. Everything that motivated my every breath while I was alive is meaningless now. (beat) I guess that's how I can be sure I'm really dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila watches the slowly churning tape recorder reels, fixated. The cop who vomited is mopping it up. The other two are sipping coffee. Lila talks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My story begins when I was twelve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (checks watch) Jesus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's got that faded, "memory" look. Twelve year old Lila hurries home from school, books clutched to her chest. Other kids walk along the street in pairs or groups, laughing and chatting. Lila walks alone, a worried scowl on her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Something terrible happened when I was twelve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Colors are still muted. It looks to be somewhere in the early 70's based on the preponderance of Bay City Rollers posters on the wall. Twelve year old Lila enters the room, closes the door, locks it, rattles the doorknob to make sure that the door is really locked. She draws the shades. She pulls some t-shirts from her dresser drawer and stuffs them into the space between the bottom of the door and the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila stands nervously in front of the full-length mirror on her closet door. She takes a deep breath and begins to unbutton her shirt, watching herself carefully in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila's shirt is now unbuttoned. She pulls it open. She is wearing a training bra over the very beginning of breast buds. On the chest above the bra, and on her stomach below it, is hair. Dark curly hair. She stares at it, touches it cautiously. Then she starts to cry. She crouches into a ball and weeps.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (muffled) Hey, no fair!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drop dead, Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Something terrible started to happen to my body when I was twelve. My mother said because of it I would never be able to get a man, so I should get used to the idea of dedicating my life to the pursuit of knowledge, or religion... or whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The doctor said...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Old fashioned office. Twelve year old Lila sits on the examination table, her shirt off. An elderly male doctor touches the hair, fingers it. Her mother looks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young Lila turns to the camera.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the mother) It's hormonal. Nature is a funny and complex thing. It could get worse with time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By the time I was twenty I looked like an ape.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The cop who vomited, gags again. Lila stares at him. Her face is hard, blank. She stubs out her cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Puff testifies before the committee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think there's anyone in the world who doesn't know by now that I was raised in the wilderness by an ape. Well, to be fair, by a man who thought himself an ape, but it amounts to the same thing gentlemen, does it not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . This has a faded, "memory" look also. A naked, bearded, dirty middle-aged man and a naked, dirty ten year old Puff walk along like apes, crouched over and dragging their knuckles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My father escaped from a New Jersey mental institution in 1963.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's raining and deserted. Puff's father, in pajamas, comes tearing around the corner. He runs crazily towards the camera, waving his arms, puffing out his cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Puff's father passes a newspaper vending machine, stops, goes back and examines the headline. It reads: President Kennedy Assassinated. Puff's father looks heavenward and clutches at his temples in despair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) He had been committed the previous year after applying one too many times at our local zoo for the job of "apprentice ape."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My father saw what the human race had come to while he was... in captivity. He felt something had to be done to create a better world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Puff's father climbs out a second story window with a small bundle in his arms. He runs off into the night.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) He stole little me from my mother, his ex-wife, and raised me, with love and tenderness and respect, as an ape like himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Puff looks pointedly at the congressman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The congressmen are shamed: they look down, they take notes, they mumble instructions to the assistants seated behind them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Apes don't assassinate their presidents, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An adult Puff and his now older father sit on the forest floor and pick bugs off each other and eat them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Until quite recently I believed myself to be an ape, although I didn't know specifically what type. Apes don't think in terms of type.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Puff testifies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Puff holds up an illustration of a pygmy chimp. Several reporters run from the room: a scoop!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It might be argued, gentlemen, that apes don't even know that they are apes. In retrospect, however, I'd say that I was a pygmy chimp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Nathan talks to nobody in particular.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I have to say I always hated apes. Of course I don't any longer. I don't even know what hate means now. But while alive, I hated apes. I blame my parents. I mean, I don't blame them. I don't know what blame is, really, anymore, but I think they influenced me in my ape-hating tendencies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Faded colors. Ten year old Nathan in a bow tie and shortpanted suit walks along with his uptight, British parents. They arrive at the ape pen. Nathan is excited. He jumps up and down. The apes jump up and down also.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a commotion off screen. Two uniformed attendants drag Puff's father, straitjacketed and kicking and screaming like an ape, past Nathan and his parents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nathan, his father, and the other zoo patrons look on curiously, a little frightened. Nathan's mother chooses to ignore it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Monkeys! Look, mama, monkeys!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (clamping down on his shoulder) Nathan, those are not monkeys. Those are apes. Mountain Gorillas to be precise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am not a human being! I am an animal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And furthermore... Tell him, Harold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distracted) Uh... (then by rote) We must never act like apes, son. For you see, The ape is our closest biological relative -- specifically the pygmy chimp. (holds up the same illustration of a pygmy chimp that Puff showed the congressional committee) A single chromosome separates us. But you know what truly separates us from the apes, what makes us better than apes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, papa. What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Culture. Civilization. Refinement. If we do not have these as humans, then we might as well be living in pens and throwing our feces about, masturbating in public... (beat, a reverie) ...sniffing red swollen female rump...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enough, Harold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila lights a new cigarette with her spent one. She drags.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I had sexual urges. I had the urge to merge, officers. Inside I was 100% Grade A female. (laughs derisively) But what self-loathing I felt! Who would have someone as repulsive, as unladylike as me? I did everything I could to shield the world from this repulsiveness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Stockings hang over the shower curtain rod. The window shade is drawn. Towels are stuffed in the space under the door. A twenty year old naked Lila is covered with shaving cream, face to feet. She is shaving. There is a pounding on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens. Lila freezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila is mortified.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Lila, what are you doing in there? I need to get ready for my date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing! I'll be out in a minute!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I'll just... (stops in her tracks when she sees Lila) What the...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila is sitting in her bathrobe on her bed and staring out the window. There is a bit of shaving cream behind her ear. Her roommate runs back and forth getting ready for her date.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door slams. Lila hugs her knees to her chest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know why you didn't tell me about this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's embarrassing, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not so bad. (beat) So, it just keeps growing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, Natalie. It's hair. It grows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, don't jump down my throat. I'm just trying to help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is that helping, Natalie? How exactly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, if you're going to be like that... You should be appreciative that I'm interested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, because I'm a freak and you are beautiful, and you are being nice enough to come down to my freak, nonbeautiful level and act concerned about my repulsive troubles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pegged) You're fucked up, Lila. (out the door) Why don't you fucking try electrolysis or something? Figure it out for chrissake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) At sixty dollars an hour, electrolysis was not a feasible solution. I explored my alternatives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Twelve year old Lila walks sadly through an art museum. she looks at various old portraits of men. She studies their facial hair. When she turns a corner, she is shocked to see a large Renaissance painting of a naked woman entirely covered with fur. She hurries to it. She looks at the placard next to the painting. It is a painting of Mary Magdalene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I remember once coming across a painting of Mary Magdalene entirely covered with fur. I guess that's where I got the idea that maybe the Catholic Church might be a place that encouraged excessive hair growth in its women.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila, in a nun's habit, is on her knees praying.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) So I became a nun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heavenly Father... (sighs) ...please let this hair go away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) But my prayers were always so selfish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A bunch of naked women dance and chat around a campfire. Lila is there, pretty hairy. So are many of the other women.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I tried being a lesbian separatist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chanting) A woman without a man / Is like a fish without a bicycle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) But I guess I just wasn't attracted to women, even hostile, man-hating, hairy ones who wore sensible shoes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila, in a full beard, sits on a throne before a crowd of gawking, dumb-looking, mouth-breathing children. Next to her on a separate stage is a sour-looking, middle-aged midget man sitting on a throne, staring blankly into space.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) For a while I was a professional circus freak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila, in a Santa suit, with beard sprayed white, sits on a throne in front of a crowd of gawking, dumb-looking, mouth- breathing children. One of them is on her lap. Next to her sits the sour midget, dressed in an elf suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kid pulls Lila's beard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) During the holiday season, they made us wear costumes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (depressed) Ho ho ho.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not real.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ow! You little fuck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Aside from the great dental, this occupation was not pleasant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila walks home. She's wrapped in winter clothing, but we can still see a bit of her white beard. It's snowing. The street is deserted. She spots a lighted window, she peers in. It's a warm family scene. Large group of chatting, laughing people. Fire in the fireplace. Big turkey on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila looks down the street and sees dozens of lonely-looking people peering forlornly in warmly lit windows. Some on ladders to peer in second-floor windows. Lila sighs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) They say the holidays are difficult for a lot of people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The room is lit with candles. Lila finishes shaving herself all over. Then she takes the double-edged blade out of the razor and climbs into the a bathtub filled with warm water. She is about to slice her wrists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the shelf next to the tub a little gray mouse watches her intently. At first she is startled, but then she and the creature seem to be communing. His little black beady eyes reflect the light. Lila starts to cry. She puts down the blade.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I decided there was something poetic about killing myself with a razor blade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila wipes a tear from her eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cops look up, on the spot. It seems their minds were elsewhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila sighs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The way that mouse looked at me. There was no judgement. It didn't care if I had hair all over my body. I was just what I was. I felt so free. Do you understand what I'm saying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something about a mouse, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a tent in a clearing. A smoking campfire. There is a rustling inside the tent. Lila steps out naked. She is covered with fur. She pours a cup of coffee, and stands, comfortable in her skin, watching the world around her. Squirrels jump from tree to tree, birds look down at her. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila picks up a pad and pen from a rock, sits on the rock and writes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Birds and squirrels and rocks and trees didn't seem to judge my hair. I felt at peace when there were no humans around. I figured out a way to spend as much time as possible with no people around. I became a nature writer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A woman under a hair drier reads a book intently. We see the first sentence of the chapter: "Last night I almost died on this mountain top." We hear Lila's dramatic reading competing with the very loud sound of the hair drier.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Last night I almost died on this mountain top, and the irony is I had never felt more alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is a violent, violent storm. The hair drier drone has turned into the explosive noise of rain beating down in sheets and wind howling at fifty miles an hour. Branches crack. Lila's tent blows over, revealing her huddled there with a sleeping bag wrapped around her like a blanket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lightning hits a tree nearby. It falls with a smack practically on top of Lila. She screams, then defiantly stands, throwing off the sleeping bag. The wind and rain whip her hair around her head. She laughs with amazing gusto and raise her arms like a runner winning a marathon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I knew it was coming when in late afternoon, a thunderhead drifted over, sneaking in like kids through the back door of a movie theater, forced casual. It turned the sky a queer shade of green. A green that said "watch out, baby, this is gonna hurt like hell." I could've hightailed, but that would be cheating. Part of the Nature experience is recognizing its mastery over you, your smallness in the face of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As Nietzsche said, what does not kill me makes me stronger, and that goes double if you're a woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see many copies of a book entitled "Wind in my Hair" by Lila Jute.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I became a successful nature writer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a woman under a hair drier reading "Wind in my Hair". We pull back to see that a long row of women under hair driers are reading Lila's book. They all stand defiantly, proudly, knocking their hair driers up and back as they do. The blowing hair driers whip the women's wet hair around their heads. The blowing hair drier drone is unbearably loud.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Then I became a famous nature writer. I said to myself, fuck humanity...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A big display of the book "Fuck Humanity" by Lila Jute. A long line of women with beautifully coiffured hair snakes out of the store.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and I became a recluse. I had a menagerie of animals at my house. They loved me because I was me. They loved me on the days I shaved. They loved me on the days I didn't. For a while this was enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila lies in bed tapping on a lap top. A dog lies with her and licks her knee. She seems to enjoy it, and gets lost in a reverie. The dog morphs into a handsome man, kissing her knee and working his way up her thigh and under her nightgown. Lila is getting seriously hot and bothered. Her head lolls. But the reverie dissipates and the man turns back into a dog rooting around her crotch with his cold nose. She pushes him away. The dejected dog gets off the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila gets out of bed and studies herself in the mirror. She brushes her hands against her hairy body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mirror image of Lila shimmers and turns into Lila with no body hair. Lila all made-up and with a smart new hairstyle. She assumes a coquettish pose and smiles cutely at herself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) By the time I was thirty I was very, very horny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had to have a man in my... life. At any cost. I would become what I needed to become to achieve this. I would become a hairless lie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was rich enough for electrolysis by this time, so I began the long arduous process of having each inappropriate hair burned out of my body at the root.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila talks. One of the cops is doodling. One is picking wax from his ear with a pencil. One is reading a paperback novel under the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cops look up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is when everything changed, and this is where my confession really begins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lila lies shirtless on a table while Rose, her fifty year old electrologist, works on her back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Progress!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ouch. Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes, honey. Getting to be smooth smooth smooth all over. Smooth as a baby's butt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love it, Rose. I'm getting to be a real girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You still in the market for a real boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Always. Ow.

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Cause there's this guy. My brother knows him. Might be right up your alley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me. I could use someone up my alley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playing dumb) I don't get that. Is that sexual?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up and tell me.

dialogue.raw_text: Handsome, thirties, psychologist...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Loves animals? Ouch. Must love animals, Rose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Loves animals. Loves you.

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somehow it came up that you were a friend of mine. Mr. handsome, animal- loving psychologist said he would love to meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Holy shit. Your brother didn't tell him about the nature of our relationship, did he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My brother is discreet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rubbing her hand over her jaw) Won't he be able to tell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My brother says the guy's a thirty- five year old virgin, so maybe he won't know how women usually feel. Plus he's got bad eyesight, almost legally blind, which is helpful in this situation. Plus he's got an extremely small penis, of which he is "mortifyingly ashamed", so chances are he'll be so grateful for any non- judgmental attention, that he'll be yours forever.

dialogue.raw_text: God, he must be really close to your brother to tell him such personal stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well my brother is his shrink.

direction.raw_text: It's a chi-chi place. Lila sits at a table with Nathan, fastidious in dress and manner. There is an awkward firstdate silence. She sneaks a glance at his crotch. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nathan blushes. Lila stares at him for a long moment. Her thoughts are unreadable.

dialogue.raw_text: Meditations on a Banana Slug was a delightful read.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you so much. I love slugs. All slugs, not just banana slugs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As do I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're so even keel. They forge ahead with slow determination. They don't get distracted or side-tracked. They don't care what they look like. They don't care that people look at them and go, "Ewww. A slug."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They don't seem to be especially ego driven, this is true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to respect that.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Slugdom. Sluggishness. Whatever you'd call it. I'm not there yet. I still have many human characteristics.
